												Ah, Tubo Dismount.  The name alone conjures up images of, well, your mom, actually, but this is not the time or the place for that particular tale.Anyway, Turbo Dismount is the heartbreaking story of Joe Dismount.  A man trapped in a world that seems to want nothing more than to push him down each time he tries to rise, and hobble him every time he tries to walk.  It's a familiar scene, the cycle of repression which seems torn straight from today's geopolitical headlines.As painful as it is to watch Joe's agonizing struggles, and I must admit it brought a tear to my eye more than once, we have to face the fact that Joe is not entirely a blameless victim here.  Joe appears to be actively seeking his own demise, and every time we see him dangling from the back of a speeding sports car, or rolling off of a cliff in an office chair, we can only wonder what horrors Joe has seen, or dare I say, even participated in, that drive this insatiable lust for the sweet release of death.We may never know, for as simple as Turbo Dismount may appear on the surface, beneath lies a complex web of tortured emotion and dark secrets best left undisturbed.  Some may view Joe as a hero, others may see him as a villan, but where Turbo Dismount succeeds in uniting us, is that we can all see Joe torn into little pieces strewn across a highway in the middle of a twenty vehicle pileup.  I suppose that in the end, that's all that really matters.

												Watching a ragdoll with Kanye West's head ride on a motorbike into a pile of bricks is probably the most fun I will ever have in a video game. I've nearly played a whole day of just sending these men in monster trucks into high-speed traffic, and then observing their limbs torn away from their body in slow motion. This is Turbo Dismount.Turbo Dismount is one of these few arcade games that I don't get bored with after about an hour or so. Normally I would play this game for a bit, but then get tired of seeing the same thing over and over. But the vast variety in Turbo Dismount is hands down the best thing about this $10 gem.Customization in Turbo Dismount is everywhere. You could paste your logo onto the front of a sports car, while Mr. Dismount clings on to the spoiler for dear life as he is shot up ramp leading to space, or make him lie down on a skateboard and push him off a cliff. There are around twenty vehicles in the game, but this number will grow with frequent updates. These vehicles include the super fast "Wedge", to the strange shopping cart, the "Mall Racer". All of which have unique speed and maneuverability.Levels in Turbo Dismount are what make the game shine. The sheer amount of variation with obstacles and level design is what sets Turbo Dismount apart. One of my personal favourites, "Freeway" has you atop a broken bridge, where poor Mr. Dismount is flung off and plummets onto a busy freeway, meeting his demise below a wreckage of cars. One other amazing thing about Turbo Dismount is the replay system. This allows you to pause, reverse or fast-forward your current dismount. You are able to see what caused the crash, viewing it at up to 1/16x slower or 4x faster.Another huge plus is the Steam Workshop. Using Unity, a video game development program, and the free Turbo Dismount package, you can create levels for Turbo Dismount and upload them to Steam. I myself have sometimes made strange and crazy paths of destruction, using Turbo Pads and traffic to my advantage. There is also optional Controller Support, which I found quite confusing while using my Xbox One controller.Overall Turbo Dismount is definitely worth the money, and with ample achievements, customization and leaderboards, there is enough content to keep you playing for a lot longer that you though you might have. Turbo Dismount is definitely one of those must-have games, and one that won't be leaving my Installed list any time soon.9.8/10

Turbo Dismount is where the little guy pedals his tricycle off of a cliff and down five stories onto landmines which launch him up into the air. 												I have played the prequel to this game. Stair Dismount for mobile devices. It was one of the best time-wasters I had ever played, and Turbo Dismount, the sequel that I never even fathomed would be made, is even better than the prequel. You have a selection of quite a few different vehicles, from a monster truck to a skateboard to a red Angry Bird to a fire truck and everything in between. You also have different poses to choose from specific to each vehicle. You choose the map, speed, and GET ♥♥♥♥ING WRECKED by whatever you run into. It could be traffic, a brick wall, landmines, or scenery. It's so fun to see your little dude get mauled by everything in sight. That sounds messed up and quite gruesome, but there is no blood or gore in the game, however, there IS dismemberment, and I'm pretty sure that someone in the future will find a way to make a bloody mod for the game. The physics are well-done in some parts and downright hilarious in others, like when you run into traffic, and then there's a pileup and cars go flying everywhere. If there is one questionable thing I have to say about physics, it's how the guy, if he gets flung into the air, he will slowly stop spinning while in the air. This defies physics and just bugs me a bit for some reason I don't understand. There are also modded levels you can make for the game, which gives the fans something to do to contribute to the game. All in all, this is a time-waster worth the money. It's fun and hilarious and the modding community is very creative. Final Score: 8.75/10.

												I'm sure that many of those interested in buying this game were convinced to do so after watching a number of YouTube personalities ♥♥♥♥ themselves laughing. I was the same way at one point. Take my advice: just watch those videos some more. They're way more fun than the actual game.The objective of Turbo Dismount is to orchestrate vehicular accidents that cause as much damage as possible to your vehicle and the hapless mannequin forced into this dilemma. You have at your disposal various maps, vehicles, obstacles to litter the course with, and poses for your mannequin. If you've seen any of the aforementioned YouTube videos, you're no doubt aware of the sort of destruction that can ensue. This would be all fine and dandy if it actually felt like the player had any real control over the outcomes of these crashes.Accelerating the vehicle consists of holding down a button and releasing it at the moment when a meter is at the desired level. Because of how obscenely quickly the meter fills up and then empties again, precise timing is nearly impossible. This is compunded by the vehicles' tendency to do whatever they want to, such as letting up on the gas when you want them to speed up, vice versa. Many of the obstacles frequently fail to produce an intended effect, and sometimes fail to produce any effect at all. Even in levels that involve other traffic, those other vehicles appear in random order and speed by so quickly that it's nigh impossible to properly time a collision.The physics engine is capable, but unpredictable. A satisfying crash can have vehicle and body parts being strewn about and colliding with each other in amusing ways, but these moments are scarce thanks to the physics' refusal to behave consistently. It's also frustrating how your ragdolling mannequin often struggles to maintain its pose, or even stay attached to the vehicle, in order to have it hit something in a desired manner.All of these frustrations combine to form an experience that is usually comprised of restarting a level over and over and over again to get a desired result. When a beautiful catastrophe does happen, it tends to feel less like the results of the player's planning and effort, and more like the result of unintentional happenstance. Even if the player learns the mechanics and nuances well enough to consistently create satisfying crashes, what's left at that point is just a shallow, one-note time waster. Ragdoll crashes car. Ragdoll goes ragdolling. Oh, how the lolz are killing me.Turbo Dismount is a one-trick pony that ♥♥♥♥s up its one trick nine times out of ten. It may be worth getting if you have some easily amused eight-year-old children in your home who are in need of a distraction. Maybe you're into the sort of boring Sunday afternoon that's reminiscent of tossing about Legos in a feeble effort to create imaginary explosions. Otherwise, don't bother.

												The premise of this game is kinda dumb and I wasn't so sure about it. However, it became side-splitting fun very quickly.  Say what you will about any game but if it can literally make me laugh out loud them I'm going to like it. Games like Deadpool, for example, have this same quality.  Basically what you're doing is setting up one of your two customizable characters in a sandbox track type environment for various ways to do serious bodily harm to them.  Its basically like when you were a little kid and would set up a toy soldier on a little obstacle course with cars, explosions, and all of that sort of thing except it is virtual and freeking hilarious.  I've also heard this called a crash test dummy sim and I suppose that is fair too.  All I know is I think other people with a childish sense of humor like mine who like games will probably enjoy Turbo Dismount.  The gamer chooses a course, sets up some obstacles, picks a mode of transportation (cars, bikes, skateboard, etc) a customizable Mr or Ms Dismount character, and the position on the vehicle for the character, then sends them on the way to certain death.  Once the dismount is achieved the whole scenario can be rewound and played back at various speeds to your liking either for your own entertainment or to help decide how to tweak the course.  Everything in the game seems well done.  I haven't encountered anything to complain about.  The graphics are simple but highly adequate and the camera system is great.  If I had to complain about any one thing is that I'd like to see more obstacles and perhaps a user picked starting point.  Its not a big deal and perhaps is something left for the next version.  I'm not much of a multi-player type of person for the most part but I can see where this would be fun to play with someone else.

												INTRODUCTIONTurbo dismount is a game I've put a lot of time into. The graphics are great, the possibilities are nearly infinite, and the workshop has thousands of levels. If you want to get the game, yet you are still slightly skeptical, here's my review on Turbo Dismount.STORYOh, story. Yeah, this game has none! The most a completionist can do is play all the pre-made levels and get all the achievements, which will still take around 20-30 hours. The point of Turbo dismount is to mess around with what you got. I've (so far) put around 27 hours into the game and I still can't get enough of the game.FEATURESThe game comes with some levels to mess around in, but you can always download levels from the steam workshop if you get tired of those levels. You can choose several vehicles, which are all unique in their own way. There's a Tricycle, Fire truck, Wrecking ball, Skateboard, Sports car, etc. If you are wondering, you can choose different characters that can pose and be customized. One of my friends had fun putting the face of Donald Trump on his character, then he would do whatever he wanted to. For poses, there's tons of them, exclusive to each character. Yes, you can do a Miley Cyrus pose on the wrecking ball, and you can do poses on the Wastelander (Inspired by the Mad Max films) that are related to the movies. There's also obstacles you can place down such as a speed boost pad and ramps.GAMEPLAYAfter choosing your character, vehicle, pose, and obstacles, you have to hold down [SPACE BAR] to adjust speed. It's a frustrating task because if you release it at the wrong time, you can go really slow, or way to fast for you to comprehend.  I can still use turbo pads to go fast though, because I usually want to go fast. Characters can have their bones broken, dismembered, twisted the opposite direction, etc, and makes the game more interesting. The physics engine is not realistic though. Once I was using a skateboard and my head got blown off from a wooden paddle when I was only going around a smooth 20 mph ( around 32 kph for foreigners).AUDIOThe SFX is clear and more realistic than the physics engine. The sounds bones crushing and muscles tearing is what gets me. I probably wouldn't have laughed at this game if SFX and the music weren't there. The music is a jazzy rhythm, and makes the game seem like an overly-edited fail compalation that you can control.PLAYABILITYThe game has barely any glitches, and recieves laughs from anybody who watches it or plays it. It has the perfect blend of humor and control of paths that I like. This is a must play when my friends come over, and we end up putting 1 or 2 hours of into it everytime. We can laugh at the insanity that happens before our eyes when our character gets blown up by a mine and afterwords mauled by a snow plow. If your mind is thinking "Why would you laugh at that, ONLY SADISTIC MINDFREAKS WOULD LAUGH AT THAT!", well I have a claim. Your so called "character" is a test dummy, and the game is only a simulation. Also you would be calling Jacksepticeye, Markiplier, Pewdiepie, Kwebblelkop, Ssunde, Ihascupquake, and DanTDM sadistic mindfreaks ( If you don't know who they are, look them up on a trusty site I call Youtube).SUM UP:DO I RECCOMEND THIS GAME?I reccomend this game to a certain crowd. If you are easlily offended, than no. Despite a couple cons, it's definitely the most fun I've had destroyng stuff on my PC (Just Cause 3 is on my XBOX One, so I'm specifying to PC), and is no doubt, a "kinetic tragedy"(that's the games slogan)My rating? 8.25 out of 10. You can play it with friends, family, yourself, and can see what sort of crazy things the community has done because I forgot to mention that you can upload gifsBy, InfernoLizard64

												When I played PAIN for the PS3, it was mostly just a fun little time waster that I would play for minutes at a time before I either managed to pull off the stunt that I had been trying, or I realized I had other games that I wanted to make progress on.Turbo Dismount is a lot like that. Unlike PAIN, however, I found Turbo Dismount more entertaining.PAIN had optional objectives that you could complete at any time to unlock a few things here and there, but any sort of objective or unlock system makes screwing around feel kinda weird and almost unenjoyable. You feel like you're not accomplishing anything, and there are things that you might want but you won't get by messing around. PAIN also had an immature sense of humor (using a donut shop to make ♥♥♥♥ jokes? Seriously?) that just turns me away for some reason.Turbo Dismount on the other hand, has no objectives or unlockables. In other kinds of games, this would be a VERY BAD THING. But in a game like this, it works really well for some reason. Choose a level, select a vehicle, and hit the accelerator. And hocus pocus, just like that, you've caused a major traffic pileup (you jerk).Another great part of Turbo Dismount is how smooth the replay system is. The replay system in PAIN is oddly awkward to use for some reason, but Turbo dismount somehow gets it incredibly right by giving you no controls other than playback speed and camera movement.Turbo Dismount also features dismemberment (that is not at all gory, because the characters are pretty much just crash test dummies), which makes everything SO much more satisfying. You'll find out what I mean when you ask yourself "wait, what happened to his head, and where's one of his arms?" then you realize that you have no idea when he lost his head/arm, and you don't know where they went. And that all works really well with the replay system, because you can find out what happened to said head/arm.Turbo Dismount is just a fun little game to waste time on.Another thing: this is just a more interesting version of Stair Dismount, which you can grab for your smartphone. But this one is WAY better.

								I would recommend this game. Although I feel the price is a bit high, the more content it gets the more it will be worth, and I anticipate the price to equal the content very soon. It is a ragdoll physics game where you aim your cars with your ragdoll inside towards various dangers, some of which you control. You choose some of the obstacles, the speed and the direction, but you CANNOT steer the cars. I was put off by that because I expected to be able to, but I was quite satisfied regardless. The map veriety is excellent already as is the selection of cars and obstacles.Pros: -Good content and veriety. More to come.-Fun and entertaining-good FPS and graphicsCons:-Scoreboard glitches, forget's your score/doesn't count it.-Inability to control the car or person's movements after dismount begins. Advice for developers: I would propose something akin to the "Burnout" series method of slightly affecting your player's movements after the crash. Otherwise, keep the new content coming and great job so far!

								When I saw this game hit Steam’s Early Access page today (January 10th, 2014), I knew that I had to reach out to the developer and inquire about a press copy (a big thank you to Jani Kahrama from Secret Exit Ltd. for accommodating).  I am a big fan of games that feature realistic physics and so far, “Turbo Dismount” isn’t disappointing.  Just to give you a bit of perspective, “Turbo Dismount” was inspired by “Stair Dismount”, a personal impact simulator, released back in 2002.  In “Turbo Dismount”, you’ll be doing your darndest to cause bodily harm to Mr. Dismount in order to maximize the number of points you receive.  To add insult to injury, you can crop photos of your friends’ faces onto Mr. Dismount…there’s no better “thinking of you” card out on the market.  For obvious reasons, this game assumes that you have a sense of humor…if you don’t, you may not want to read any further.As noted above, the game is still in development so a review is not ethically possible at this point.  Still, the game is pretty fun, even in its current state.

												Not at all a deep game, and you don't actually get to drive any of the vehicles. So, it's not really anything like HappyWheels, which is a disappointment. The meat of the game is picking obstacles to put on the map, pick a vehicle, and determine how fast it will go on it's imaginary rail. So, from an interaction standpoint, it's actually a bit dull.But the reason I've put a few hours into this is that the physics engine is really good (aside from the cars that make up CPU traffic weighing about 5kg's each), and the rag-doll mechanic is consistently funny in at least a minor way. Plus, it's what I'd call a 60-second game: you can play it in the few minutes extra you have between being ready for work and actually having to leave. Really, it's a good way to get a chuckle if you are running ahead of your schedule and have a few minutes. It's the sort of game you can enjoy without needing more than a minute, unlike many games, and it's cheap enough that the lack of depth isn't a problem.But only if you can get past the lack of interaction. The spectacle is fun, and there's enough options and choices to set-up your crashes and jumps for the vehicles, but my recommendation is only a marginal thumbs-up since there's no actual driving and the spectacle is only going to get you so far. Again, you can't actually drive the vehicles, and the level of interaction is very low besides just choosing a car, speed, maps, and placing a couple obstacles. But it's worth it for a game to have when you just want to have a laugh in the minute or two before having to do something else.(FINAL NOTE: Around 10 of my hours were gained because of forgetting the game was on after I went to bed. As I said before, it's not something you'd expect to put much time into, but the time does add up if you mess around 5 minutes here or there during a work-week or school week. Really, I think I'm at actually a little over a dozen hours).
